awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Hyper Suprime-Cam Wide Emission-Line Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
The epoch of reionization, when the intergalactic gas went from being neutral and opaque to being very highly ionized, and therefore transparent, is a key period in the evolution of the Universe. Determining the redshift when this occurred and the sources of the photons that ionized the intergalactic gas represents one of the current frontiers in observational cosmology.  The enormous recent progress in identifying populations of high-redshift galaxies, particularly the Lyman alpha emitting galaxies, has the potential to answer the question of when this process occurred. This project will develop large, homogeneous galaxy samples with which to determine the properties of the ultra-luminous galaxies at high redshift.  An important aspect of this project is to provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students that will engage their interest and encourage their participation in science, train them in observational methods and instruments, direct them in computer processing and reduction techniques for large imaging and spectroscopic data sets, and provide mentoring, with a particular emphasis on encouraging women students. 

Observations suggesting a drop in the high-redshift Lyman Alpha Emitter (LAE) fraction beyond a redshift of seven have been interpreted as marking the onset of reionization at this redshift.  However, the most luminous LAEs do not appear to show such an evolution and may also exhibit more complex line profiles than lower-luminosity LAEs, suggesting that the most luminous LAEs are protecting themselves from the evolving neutrality of the IGM by generating highly ionized surroundings.  As a consequence, the galaxy can be seen directly without scattering from the surrounding intergalactic medium.  The aim of the proposed survey is to observe a 120 square degree field to moderate depth using Hyper Suprime-Cam on the Subaru telescope in order to develop a large uniformly-selected sample of very luminous LAEs, as well as a very large sample of more moderate-luminosity LAEs from which we can determine the properties of  LAEs from redshift 5 to redshift 7. From these samples, the researchers will be able to determine how LAEs depend on environment and luminosity in this redshift range, as well as estimate the ionizing photon production in the most luminous LAEs and the growth of HII porosity. Determining properties of galaxies near the reionization boundary, and particularly their ionizing photon production, will provide strong constraints on theoretical models of the evolution of the intergalactic gas, the evolution of galaxies, and structure formation at high redshift.

por.por_cntn:
Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies (LAEs), young galaxies that emit Lyman-alpha radiation from neutral hydrogen, are powerful diagnostics of the early history of our Universe, when the intergalactic gas transitioned from being substantially neutral to mostly ionized in the first billion years. Determining when this "epoch of reionization" occurred, and the sources of the photons that ionized this gas is one of the current frontiers of cosmology and a key focus of recently launched spacecraft missions (James Webb Space Telescope and Euclid).


In this project we used imaging from the Hyper Suprime-Cam instrument of the Subaru instrument on Mauna Kea to develop uniform samples of very luminous LAEs near the reionization boundary to try to understand the properties of the intergalactic gas that facilitates the escape of ionizing photons. We used spectra taken with the DEIMOS spectrograph on the Keck telescope on Mauna Kea to confirm these sources as LAEs and to look for uniques signatures in the line profiles suggesting these galaxies formed ionized bubbles that facilitate the escape of photons. A sample of 21 such very luminous LAEs were found.


We probed the evolution of early LAEs in two ways: (1) by mapping the velocity widths of the Lyman-alpha line profiles, finding a significant narrowing of the Lyman-alpha line at lower luminosities and a distribution of components on both red and blue sides of the central line, and (2) by looking for number density evolution at the highest luminosities, finding consistency with no evolution. All of our results are consistent with the ionized bubble interpretation for the most luminous LAEs, since the increasing neutrality of the gas at earlier times would have less of an impact on these galaxies. If such galaxies produce the bulk of the ionizing photons, then this is a major paradigm shift from current models, which have had the photons responsible for ionizing the hydrogen in the universe arising from the very faint end of the galaxy distribution. It is likely that these multiple systems indicate patchy reionization that can be explored in greater detail with additional space missions, such as the James Webb Space Telescope.

We trained undergraduate and graduate students in the reduction, analysis, and interpretation of wide-field optical imaging and spectroscopy, preparing them for STEM careers. We also lead students to use machine learning methods to analyze large catalog data sets to help with the analysis of imaging data to learn important technical skills, and to experience the research process from beginning to end.  In the process, we encouraged them to work collaboratively with other students, postdocs, and faculty members.
